G.L. c. 208, \u00a7 28.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Sarah Johnson (“Plaintiff” or “Mother”), and respectfully files this Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 7, seeking modification of the judgment of custody and parenting time entered by this Honorable Court on April 15, 2021.

G.L. c. 209C, \u00a7 20.proposition: Now comes the Plaintiff, Sarah Johnson (“Plaintiff” or “Mother”), and respectfully files this Complaint for Modification pursuant to G.L. c. 208, § 28, G.L. c. 209C, § 20, and Mass. R. Dom. Rel. P. 7, seeking modification of the judgment of custody and parenting time entered by this Honorable Court on April 15, 2021.

Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.proposition: A party seeking modification must show both (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the earlier judgment, and (b) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.support_reasoning: This case is an initial divorce and custody/removal decision, not a post‑judgment modification proceeding. The opinion discusses standards for awarding custody and for permitting removal of children from the Commonwealth, framed in terms of the best interests of the child and the custodial parent’s ‘real advantage,’ but it does not set out or apply a rule that a party seeking modification must show a material and substantial change in circumstances since an earlier judgment. Therefore, it does not support the specific modification proposition stated.
Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 7.relevant_excerpt: The Massachusetts removal statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30 (1984 ed.), provides that “[a] minor child of divorced parents who is a native of . . . this commonwealth . . . shall not, if of suitable age to signify his consent, be removed out of this commonwealth without such consent, or, if under that age, without the consent of both parents, unless the court upon cause shown otherwise orders.” The words “upon cause shown” mean only that removal must be in the best interests of the child (Rubin v. Rubin, 370 Mass. 857 [1976]; Hale v. Hale, supra at 815), and thus the central question in this case is how these “best interests” are to be determined.

Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).proposition: A party seeking modification must show both (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the earlier judgment, and (b) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).support_reasoning: The opinion is a removal/relocation decision under G.L. c. 208, § 30, not a general modification standard. It frames the governing test as whether removal is in the children’s best interests and discusses “cause shown,” but it does not state that a party seeking modification must first prove a material and substantial change in circumstances in addition to best interests. The only mention of ‘substantial change in circumstances’ appears in a quoted ALI Principles passage about relocation, not as Massachusetts’ required two-prong standard for modification generally.
Mason v. Coleman, 447 Mass. 177 (2006).relevant_excerpt:
The Principles of the Law of Family Dissolution § 2.17 (2002), as adopted and promulgated by the American Law Institute, state in pertinent part:
“(1) The relocation of a parent constitutes a substantial change in circumstances . . . only when the relocation significantly impairs either parent’s ability to exercise responsibilities the parent has been exercising or attempting to exercise [under the judgement of divorce] …
“(4) When a relocation constituting changed circumstances . . . renders it impractical to maintain the same proportion of custodial responsibility to each parent, the court should modify the parenting plan in accordance with the child’s best interests ...”

Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).proposition: A party seeking modification must show both (a) a material and substantial change in circumstances since entry of the earlier judgment, and (b) that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).support_reasoning: The case sets out the standard for modification of alimony or child support as requiring a material change in circumstances since the earlier judgment, citing Schuler v. Schuler. It does not state that a party must also show that the proposed modification is in the best interests of the child; indeed, this case is about alimony between former spouses and does not involve or analyze any best-interests-of-the-child requirement. Thus it supports only part (a) of the proposition, not the combined (a)+(b) standard claimed.
Pierce v. Pierce, 455 Mass. 286 (2009).relevant_excerpt: “‘To be successful in an action to modify a judgment for alimony or child support, the petitioner must demonstrate a material change of circumstances since the entry of the earlier judgment.’ Schuler v. Schuler, 382 Mass. 366, 368 (1981).”

Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.raw_text: Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (1981)
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.proposition: The Court has consistently held that fundamental changes in a parent’s location, employment, or the child’s schooling constitute adequate grounds for modification.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.support_reasoning: Hale v. Hale is a removal (relocation) case, not a modification case, and it does not articulate any categorical rule that fundamental changes in a parent’s location, employment, or the child’s schooling are themselves adequate grounds for modification. Instead, the court focuses on the best interests of the child in the context of relocation and stresses weighing the well-being of the custodial parent and alternative visitation arrangements. It neither discusses nor establishes a consistent line of authority using such changes as sufficient grounds for modification orders generally.
Hale v. Hale, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 812 (198.relevant_excerpt: “The Massachusetts authorities have not discussed in detail the factors to be weighed in deciding questions of removal. The words ‘upon cause shown’ in the controlling statute, G. L. c. 208, § 30, … have been interpreted to permit removal if in the best interests of the child…. We conclude that while the trial judge considered one important factor, the children’s need for weekly visitation by the noncustodial parent, we cannot ascertain whether he also took into account other, perhaps even more important, factors bearing upon their best interests.”

Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).proposition: The Court has consistently held that fundamental changes in a parent’s location, employment, or the child’s schooling constitute adequate grounds for modification.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).support_reasoning: The opinion is a divorce/property division and custody case; the only modification-related point is a narrow procedural holding that any future change in custody must proceed by complaint for modification under G.L. c. 208, § 28. The court does not discuss what substantive grounds (such as changes in location, employment, or schooling) justify modification, nor does it state any consistent rule that such "fundamental changes" are adequate grounds. Thus it does not support the proposition claimed.
Williams v. Massa, 431 Mass. 619 (2000).relevant_excerpt: "A change in a custody judgment, however, should be made pursuant to a complaint for modification under G. L. c. 208, § 28. If the judge felt that joint legal custody put the children at risk, or was not in their best interests, because of the wife’s worrisome parenting behavior, then the judge should have ordered sole legal custody to the father. She did not have discretion to fashion, even with the agreement of both parents, an alternative plan."

Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.raw_text: Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1981)
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.proposition: The Court must give paramount consideration to the best interests of the child, assessing stability, continuity, and daily routine.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.support_reasoning: The opinion clearly states that in custody matters the overriding and controlling consideration is the best interests, happiness, and welfare of the children, including consideration of their present and probable future circumstances. While the court does not use the exact words “stability, continuity, and daily routine,” it emphasizes minimizing disruption, the importance of the primary nurturing parent, and fostering a healthy environment for growth and development—concepts that substantively align with assessing stability and continuity in the child’s life.
Rolde v. Rolde, 12 Mass. App. Ct. 398 (1.relevant_excerpt: “However, in deciding issues involving custody, the overriding concern of the court must be the promotion of the best interests of the children and their general welfare… ‘In providing for the custody of a minor child, while the feelings and wishes of the parents should not be disregarded, the happiness and the welfare of the children should be the controlling consideration. It is the duty of the judge to consider the welfare of the children in reference not merely to the present, but also to the probable future…’ … The judge found the wife has been the ‘primary nurturing parent’ and ‘primary caretaker’ and that the children have the ‘strongest bond’ with their mother. These factors are highly significant for the welfare of the children, and are thus critical considerations for the judge in deciding on a custodial arrangement which minimizes disruption and fosters a healthy environment for the growth and development of the children.”

Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).proposition: The Court must give paramount consideration to the best interests of the child, assessing stability, continuity, and daily routine.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).support_reasoning: The opinion squarely applies the best-interests-of-the-child standard in determining custody and expressly lists stability-related factors such as stable home, work schedule, continuity of caregivers, and maintenance of sibling and parental relationships. It then applies those factors to the facts (multiple moves, many caregivers, long work hours versus a flexible job and stable environment) to decide physical custody, making clear that the child’s welfare and stability are paramount. This directly supports a proposition that the court must give paramount consideration to the child’s best interests, including stability, continuity, and daily routine.
Hunter v. Rose, 463 Mass. 488 (2012).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry [is]… what is ‘best for the child’…. However, the judge must weigh ‘all relevant factors in determining the best interests of the child.’ … Factors a judge may weigh are whether one parent’s home is more stable in terms of a parent’s work schedule, whether siblings are being raised together, and whether one parent seeks to undermine the relationship a child has with the other parent. … [T]he judge also assessed the stability each parent offered Jill, as well as the flexibility of each parent’s job.”

Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).proposition: The child’s welfare is the “touchstone” of every custody determination.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).support_reasoning: The opinion directly discusses the governing standard in custody matters and explains that the ‘best interests of the child’—often framed as the child’s welfare—has long been the guiding principle in Massachusetts custody decisions. The court traces this standard historically, citing prior cases that describe the child’s welfare or best interests as the paramount concern, thereby supporting the idea that the child’s welfare is the touchstone of every custody determination.
Custody of Kali, 439 Mass. 834 (2003).relevant_excerpt: “In custody matters, the touchstone inquiry of what is ‘best for the child’ is firmly rooted in American history… The ‘best interests’ standard appeared in our case law at least as early as 1865… It has been adhered to ever since. See, e.g., Blixt v. Blixt, 437 Mass. 649, 657 (2002) … Yannas v. Frondistou-Yannas, 395 Mass. 704, 710 (1985) (‘best interests of the children always remain the paramount concern’); Surrender of Minor Children, 344 Mass. 230, 234 (1962)… (‘the paramount issue is the welfare of the child’).”

Cahill v. Cahill, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 1126.raw_text: Cahill v. Cahill, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 1126 (2008) (Rule 1:28 decision)
Cahill v. Cahill, 71 Mass. App. Ct. 1126.proposition: Massachusetts courts recognize that long-distance travel and disruption of schooling are not in a child’s best interest.

Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.raw_text: Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001)
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.proposition: Pursuant to Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 257 (2001), the Court may adjust parenting time schedules to accommodate material changes in residence even absent bad faith.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.support_reasoning: The case deals with modification of custody and a custodial parent’s request to relocate, not with mere adjustment of parenting-time schedules to accommodate residence changes. The court holds that a custody modification requires a material and substantial change in circumstances beyond the move itself, and then remands for further proceedings regarding visitation; it does not articulate any general rule that courts may adjust parenting time schedules for material residence changes absent bad faith. The claimed proposition overstates and mischaracterizes the holding of Rosenthal v. Maney.
Rosenthal v. Maney, 51 Mass. App. Ct. 25.relevant_excerpt: “We remand for the entry of a judgment that the custody of the parties’ minor child remain with the mother, that she may relocate with the child to Rhode Island, ‘and for such further proceedings consistent with this opinion relative to time and conditions of visitation.’ Haas v. Puchalski, 9 Mass. App. Ct. at 558.”
